intro: Cerinthe minor subsp. minor, commonly known as the lesser cerinthe, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and features slender, upright stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are usually violet or blue in color, arranged in loose spikes at the top of the stem. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a slightly rough texture, often with a bluish-green hue. This species thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens and borders.
